description:
This place is a secret gem.  As much as I don't  want to spoil my spot, I have to spread the word, as this place is amazing.

Imagine not having to wait for a fantastic meal that is so affordable and amazing service.  This is your place.

Since the new management took over, service is quick, the food is even better, and the bill is recession friendly. By far the best breakfast in the Marina!
author: Betsy C.

description:
3.5 stars 

i really enjoyed brunch here. this is slightly hole in the wall diner type place with a huge selection of breakfast dishes. the warm fresh scones were delicious. you can get a litre of mimosas with either fresh squeezed orange juice or grapefruit juice for $24. the food was decent (not the best, but good for the type of atmosphere and price). ill be back.
author: Yevi A.

description:
The line was long and it took a long time to get seated here. I have walked by here many times and kept meaning to try it, and finally decided to try it on a weekend morning with my boyfriend and a friend that was visiting from out of town. 

Service/Atmosphere:
We had to wait outside until a table was ready, and it was a chilly morning. Our table was the one in front of the window as you walk inside, so every time someone walked in, I felt cold air. The service was ok, although a little slow in taking my table's order.

Food:
The food wasn't bad, but it wasn't memorable either. I've had better breakfasts at other places and am still in search of a breakfast place within walking distance of my apartment.

Value:
The prices were consistent with breakfast prices in the area.
author: Cynthia D.

description:
The scones and homemade jam can't be beat. Before this place, I was a scone skeptic that thought they were too dry and crumbly.  After this, I am a scone lover! Then again, maybe it's only the scones here..we shall see.

The BF and I came here awhile back on accident - we were trying to go to another place for brunch but apparently they weren't open (coughcafemaritimecough)! There was no wait around noon.  Although service was a little choppy and abrupt, it had the charm of a cafe where you can watch the magic happen in the kitchen.  The hangtown scramble (I think that's the name) with oysters, eggs, bacon, etc. was excellent but I couldn't finish them all and oysters with eggs don't really seem like something ya wanna take to go.

KEY POINTS: Check out the specials on the wall/board thing, expect a little bit of a wait cuz the place is kinda small, expect to bring change for the meters or to park at the garage around the corner unless you come on a Sunday.
author: Alice C.

description:
Home Plate has got that diner feel. 

I'm so happy to discover a new brunch spot. I must say, 3 stars for food and plus 1 extra for the cheap prices and homemade complimentary scones. 

The wait can be a bit long on the weekends, but once you're seated, they bring you homemade scones with jam to hold you over. Warm, buttery, and free! 

I was feeling particularly adventurous last Sunday, so rather than order my usual egg dish, I went with my childhood favorite- banana walnut pancakes. They were perfect. I highly recommend. 

I love their selection of bevvies (abbrev for beverages); we ordered a Pep Supreme drink, which consisted of a banana, orange juice, and a little bit of honey- it was DELICIOUS. Kind of like Razzmatazz at Jamba Juice, but not so thick and filling. 

At Home Plate, the staff was friendly, the food was pretty good, and my coffee cup was always full. Isn't that what a brunch diner is all about?
author: Laura D.

description: Food is hot, delicous, fresh and wonderful.  So many choices, and options I will come back for the best pancakes I can remember eating.  Service is strange, not friendly don't expect much.  Also tight spaces, don't set up kids under 5 for failure.
author: tonya m.

description:
Great breakfast! wonderful scones! 

stumbled upon this place in the city and had the best breakfast ever.  huge omelets.  get the parmesan pesto omelette. amazing.  homemade apple sauce and wonderful staff.  they were all so friendly.

home run.
author: lauren m.

description:
Home Plate didn't hit a home run with me but it didn't strike out either. Somewhere like 2nd base and getting ready to steal 3rd. Or in yelp stars, 3.75.

What I Really Liked:
- Friendly Service: Friendly efficient staff is always appreciated.
- Refilling Coffee: They came back 3x or 4x. That's important to never drop below 1/4 cup.
- Fresh Raisin (maybe blueberry) Scones: Comes with every breakfast item and served with a berry jam.
- Range of Menu Options: Broad selection and not always your typical picks though they offered your basic egg/toast/bacon plates too.
- Reasonably Priced: $6 - $9 on average. It's breakfast, c'mon.
- Portion: Pretty big if I do say so myself.
- Frittata: My friend ordered the Home Plate Frittata ($8.45 or $8.25) with spinach, chicken sausage, cheese and pine nuts. It was super tasty and a nice change from the usual omelette. It comes with the potato-carrot pancake everyone yelps about but I found it to be less like a pancake and more like a Chinese scallion cake (minus scallions) or a roti bread. It's flat with a chewy texture and they serve it with apple sauce. I thought it was ok, but calling it a pancake sets the wrong expectation.

What Was OK:
- Home Plate Fried Polenta ($8.25) with bacon. I love when places offer polenta at all hours. This was came in 2 square blocks with mushroom and pine nuts. I liked the crisp pan fried outside, but the inside lacked salt. So I had to season it to taste. I'm also particular about my bacon. This came with 3 crispy slices which is fine, but they were really fatty pieces such that while crisp I knew I was just ingesting fat. 
- Raisin Pecan French Toast ($2.95): We asked for a special baby side order of Raisin Pecan French Toast which they were kind enough to accommodate. Good thing we only got 2 halves (1 square slice) because it wasn't that great. Just basic.

I'd go up to bat at Home Plate again and while I won't expect any home runs, I know I'll get at least a solid a base run hit or two.
author: Cindy W.

description: This place rocks.  A welcome change from the standard Cow Hollow breakfast offerings (IHOP, Mel's, etc).  The food is really good (great scones & home made jam), and the service is friendly.  You can tell this place is privately owned, as opposed to the standard corp boys around the corner.
author: Doug V.

description:
Totally clutch for brunch. Be sure to order off the 'special' menu (the poster on the wall). The pancakes, omelets, scrambles, etc were all strong dishes. The scones are incredibly addicting, and the jam that comes with them is like crack. 

They also have some biscuit sandwiches (biscuit w/ avocado, turkey, egg, etc) - quite delicious as well :) 

Highly recommended. Not very expensive. Cute hole in the wall type of cafe. A favorite on a Sunday morning after a fun night out!
author: linda t.

description:
took my buddy phil w. here for breakfast one day.  i`d be here once before and enjoyed the breakfast, so i thought i`d share the wealth with phil!

being a huge fan of polenta, i ordered the home plate fried polenta, which comes with eggs and a choice of meat.  pan fried on the outside, the polenta is creamy on the inside, with pine nuts, mushrooms and cheese...so delicious!

phil got the blackstone benedict, which was eggs benedict with bacon instead of ham.  i had never tried eggs benedict before, so i HAD to have a bite ;D  it was very good...gooey eggs, holendaise sauce...yum!

our meal also came with homemade scones, which were little, but tasty!  their homemade jams that came with the scones actually look like ketchup and mustard LoLx  it was pretty cute :]

bottom line?  great food, awesome servers!  i will slide into home plate again very soon! [horrible pun, i know -_-" LoLx]
author: Dee W.

description:
Maybe 2.5 stars. .. 

The complementary scone was the highlight - both because it was delicious and because I was starving and needed food ASAP.

Otherwise breakfast was pretty standard - edible, far from delicious, speedy, and well priced. 

You'll find me at Bay Watch cafe up one block before you find me back here.
author: Sarah L.

description: I love their service and their food. I was eating here for almost everyday with my partner. The scones are to die for, and the pancakes are delicious. Service is quick and excellent. I will keep on coming back for breakfast/brunch when I'm in the area! This is my favorite breakfast spot in the world. I wish they had one closer to BART and in the East Bay.
author: Ali K.

description:
I would only give this place one star but because my boyfriend loves it, I will add another. I do not get it. I love sitting at the chef's table at A16- it is lively, fun and mesmerizing to watch the chefs prepare an artful delectable dish in a well maintained CLEAN kitchen. At Home Plate I can also watch the cooks make my meal but I have distasteful cringing thoughts while viewing. I am not sure how this place has ever been up to Health Code. 

It is hard to tell the last time that the jam/jelly/gelatin jar left on the table with a spoon sticking out has been cleaned, rinsed and had a new batch of whatever is supposed to be in there- added. The food itself is ok and so is the price- but nothing I am willing to risk my health for! 

Next time, I will take a seat at Ihop across the street let my boyfriend enjoy his scone covered in the mystery jam gelatin thing.
author: Megan M.

description: I won't be going back here. I heard the turkey-cashew nut hash was good. Well, it was all potato, a few tiny pieces of turkey, and huge pieces of crunchy bell peppers. I could have made this better at home, balanced with a decent amount of protein. The croissant that accompanied it was cheap freezer-quality, and this was the killer - if you look at the rungs on the chairs, they're covered - no, COATED with a thick layer of grease, grime, dust, dirt (and germs). The floor was pretty bad too, this afternoon when I visited. That was so gross, I lost my appetite. Then, when there was hardly any turkey in the turkey hash - it was a sad restaurant experience. :( Waste of money.
author: Carolyn F.

description: The selection of food here is huge.  The prices are good and the staff are really friendly. They bring you your food really fast too. Oh yes, you can't forget about the tasty scones. Every time I hear the word scone I think of Liam Gallagher of Oasis and the "incident" where he got thrown off the plane. If he had one of their scones I can I understand why he got thrown off a plane.  But I digress...the food is good and that's what matters most. It's MUCH better than IHOP.
author: Amy J.

description: not bad for your standard breakfast food. the portions are adequate and the service excellent. a constant hot, full cup of joe is a good way to gauge whether service is good at a diner type establishment. the little scones you get when you sit down is a nice touch. it's the little things, folks!
author: Regina C.

description:
First of all, a loving welcome to my guest yelper B - aka milhouse.yelp.com.

D: So after the fullness subsided and the stank of grease from Home Plate's kitchen left your hair, what did you think? (says I still full and smelling like fried eggs 12 hours later!)

B: what's wrong with smelling like egg grease?  as long as you're not sporting an expensive cashmere sweater or something, you can bring breakfast with you all day. =)  i think if we weren't sitting so close to the kitchen, we'd be ok.  but the breakfast sure was good and tasty - including a steaming hot scone makes this place a winner in my book.

D: well, as long as you like the wind of poached eggs blowing in my hair. yeah, i liked your chicken sausage egg scramble better than my eggs florentine. of course, i will always compare every benedict combo to town's end's perfect poached eggs and hollandaise sauce. *siii-gh* home plate's were a little too firm and not runny enough for my liking, and the hollandaise sauce just a little too chunky for me (have we heard of a sieve people). no, i wasn't wearing no cashmere sweater, but i usually like my "sunday brunch" venues to be fresh and so clean-clean. brunch is an affair to me! if you like to roll into your breakfast right outta bed, then home plate is surely the way to go! no doubt i'd come here again, but with my miss curious tee on, and a pair of loose pants for a straight up greasy hangover-helper meal.

B: next time we come here, we'll wear jeans and a cap and bring the sunday paper!

D: deal! you may yelp differently, but i'm giving this 3.5 stars. bumping up to four because there was no line today, our server was very friendly and timely (well, we could literally see our breakfast being made) and of the great company you always help me keep :) thanks too for yelping with me! (sometimes a girl just doesn't want to yelp alone).
author: Diana L.

description:
Great scones that are served with delicious sauce (I want to say it's a strawberry apple sauce...whatever it is, so good!) and all breakfast entrees are served with a roll and potato/carrot pancakes and sour cream.  Food is good, I've had the chorizo frittata (its greasy!) and the pancakes with fresh fruit, both good.  Breakfast places are hard to rate because breakfast foods can be made easily at home, but you go because it tastes better when someone else makes it for you.

The service is great and the wait has never been super long (maybe 10- 15min).  I find that even with so many customers, they manage to keep serving everyone well.  Wouldn't recommend for large groups of people because it's a small place.  Why wait in line at IHOP across the street when you've got this place!
author: Emiko M.

description: We are locals and love it!  Just really great, high quality, no frills, good old American food.  We had omelettes that were delicious, one egg white and one conventional.  Complementary scones were light and just the right size.  And don't get me started with their unique potato carrot pancakes, OMG.  Had a double cheeseburger there last week--made the list of top 5 ever.
author: Joseph M.

description:
Inexpensive and Quick service. For a greasy spoon I give it 4 stars.

Stick to the Specials Menu on the wall. Forget the bacon and get the chicken sausage (they are actually little patties of deliciousness that are better than Bruce Aidell's sausages). I always get the same thing: Pep Supreme (a banana-orange smoothie), eggs and chicken sausage and the Free delicious scones. My family and I order extra hot scones to take home. Their strawberry-apple, apricot-apple or raspberry-apple sauce that goes with the scones is fabu.

Have tried other things on their specials menu...omelettes are good. But, I'll stick to the basics for breakfast so I don't get the urge to lapse into a food coma by 11am.
author: L P.

description:
second time around got a chance to bring the whole fam

we all ordered a little different 

everything was perfect  

'the service was really great and looked good as well (nevermind)
from the coffee to the carrot potato pancakes the strawberry and apricot jam  and omletts were all perfect  THANK YOU
author: Marc M.

description: We were staying just a few blocks away while on vacation and found the reviews for Home Plate on Yelp. The scones were fantastic. I overheard 2 different tables order extras to go. I had the veggie omelet and which has TONS of veggies and cheese - including lots of avacado. If I'm ever in SF again, I will definitely be back.
author: Kristen S.

description: very creative menu, many home made specialties, sausage, pancakes, scones and more,  excellent flavors.
author: Dan P.

description: LOVE IT LOVE IT LOVE IT!!! What can i say that has not already been said about this place??..........Tell you what. When in SF get your Grub-On @ Home Plate. (lunch or breakfast) after your done devouring  every little morsel on ya' plate and are happy with the service and not to mention the bill... You can jump back on Yelp and thank me for this very KEEN recommendation...Your very delighted (and so will you) Gastronomic buddy,                          M S
author: M S.

description: I used to live around the corner and breakfast here at every opportunity.  Big fan of the potato pancakes and biscuits.  Yes, it is a greasy spoon and its location right on Lombard is not real inviting... but if you want a good breakfast and are willing to sacrifice atmosphere, Home Plate is the best I've had.
author: Geoff D.

description: Fantastic hole in the wall.  Service is generally efficient although slow on occassion.  Scones (come with every breakfast) are awesome!  I always buy a few to enjoy later.  The potato pancakes are yummy.  French toast combo & the special scramble are my favorites.  Pancakes are piled with fresh fruit.  Everyone who has joined me there want to return.  Food is served quickly & hot.
author: Kim S.

description: Yes, it's a hole in the wall, and the food is greasy, but man is it good. I would give it three stars except for the fact that I still vividly remember their perfect scones and it's been a couple years since I've been there.
author: Kari E.

description:
I'm surprised for all the bad reviews.. maybe I'm more forgiving than most. Anyway... Couple things:

* I was impressed by the variety and creativity there was on the "specials" menu. Lot of things I hadn't seen before

* The portions were just the right size. I left feeling satisfied. For those who want more for breakfast, I recommend Denny's Build-Your-Own-Slam®

* As others have said, the scones are good. My croissan-roll was good and fresh. 

So why not 5 stars? I would've added a meat group to the plates. A couple slices of canadian bacon would've been perfect. I wouldn't recommend parties of more than 4. And parking is... well.. its San Francisco. What can one expect?
author: clark i.

description:
Oh man how did i miss out on this breakfast haven.  I should have known with the long lines and the classy name like home plate.   A very good friend of mine, Benji, brought me here and it was like i was coming back home.  This place just had character written all over it.   I just ordered the special omelet which i cant recall the name right now and a tall OJ and just pigged the hell out!

I cant wait til i have enough time to make it out there for breakfast again.  it was heaven on earth!
author: Harry H.

description:
They rule breakfast like nerds rule Frys -- completely.

Was considering places to go with my bro and niece (age:3). He doesn't get up to SF that much since he moved down peninsula, so wanted wanted following ingredients: awesome breaky, kid friendly, not cookie-cutter.  Homerun? Done and done.

The cooks/wait-staff/owners (they seem to intermingle) are SOooo friendly, thoughtful and quick. They don't make a show of their perfect service. They just bring everything you want exactly when you want --- and it's friggin' delicious. The specials? Money. Their scrambles? Unique fresh ingredients + awesome. As they refill your coffee while you're savoring a breakfast masterpiece, you'll say: I'm goin' to Yelp the bejesus outta these guys. With some ultra-hyped breakfast spots, this one delivers the goods.
author: tom w.

description:
OK, the food is great.  The free scones rule the earth.  

But they lose a star because they need to hire a bus boy or another waitress.  I've been here a few times and the waitress just seems overwhelmed.  Each time is was here, a table is usually available, but they are un-bussed and filthy.
author: Larry A.

description:
Great brunch spot

Any place that gives you free scones to start the meal gets an A+ in my book.

I ordered the Italian omelet which was really good. The specials are great, tried the potato and regular pancakes.  Ask them for their homemade salsa, it's pretty good

The prices are great and service is excellent.  The owner is really nice.
author: Sun-Kai P.

description:
My Day In The Marina Part 2

After being about an hour early for breakfast and buy a great pair of running shoes from Fleet Feet I finally make it over to Home Plate.

I'm not to sure of what to say about home plate other than I liked the food we ordered.  I will say the strawberry and mango jam are the business and they go great on the warm scones they bring to the table. Oh my goodness they are so good. I think we could have split like 2 plates of those little goodies. 

My main course heuvos rancheros and it was delightful. The eggs were fluffy, the salsa was just right, and the black bean were great I just wish I had a little more of them. The home made corn tortilla made the meal complete. 
 Oh and wash down whatever you have with a cup of fresh squeezed OJ and you'll be one happy camper.
author: Karim R.

description:
It's not very fancy and it's pretty small inside; but I kinda like that "homey" feel. The specialty scones are as good as other Yelpers say.
My avocado burger was pretty awesome, especially for eight bucks: home made patty, fresh and crisp lettuce, juicy slice of tomato and super fresh and green (like, almost radioactive green!) avocado. The buns are also different from what you usually get in these kind of places. 
The girlfiend had some breakfast with bacon that was awesome: crispy but not burnt and not drowning in grease.
Finally, it's pretty rare in SF to find a decent size glass of fresh squeezed orange juice for under 3 bucks. They got that, and also grapefruit juice or carrot juice.
You get the picture: everything in this place has that home made feel; very very different from the chain food like ihop across the street.
Add to this very depression-friendly prices and you get a really cool brunch place you could get addicted to.

Now I don't know if the quality is always that good, but I'm ready to try again, because I was impressed. If consistently good, like every review I give, I will give them their fifth star.

One little minus: the parking situation, as expected in the Marina.
author: Vithiet L.

description: Scones are delicious!  It starts there and ends with delicious pancakes.
author: David J.

description: Yummy!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! My sister took me here and man was it good. The Scone they serve it Yummy!!!!!!!!! i always order the Chrizo sramble. Soooooooooooooooooo good. There tortilla is very good. it's light, i usually will not order a Mexican dish but since they make everything there. I mean everything. You have to try it., The service it also very good. Always packed with with people. You have to wait if you come after 11am. Worth it.  menu is huge.
author: Ge I.

description:
Their scones are soooo frickin good.  Fresh strawberry jam doesn't look that great, but that's because they didn't add food coloring to make it bright red.  It tastes homemade and I wouldn't have it any other way.  

The oyster omelette (Hangtown Fry) is a definte winner.  Has so many chunks of real fresh oyster, not just a few flecks here and there.  Also liked the the potato-carrot pancake (reminds me of a latke with a twist).

Buttermilk pancakes have great texture and taste, but needed to be cooked just a tad longer this time.  Next time, I'll ask for it to be cooked a little longer.  Coffee (had about 10 cups) was flowing and service was very friendly.

I'm gonna tell more people about this place.  Good choice everyone.  It's NOT the bfast place for everyone....it's not cute, not fancy, not super clean, not B&B in any way, BUT it's a very casual home-like place to kick back and get fed well for the price you pay.
author: Alex J.

description:
A teeny tiny hole in the wall that serves up a wide variety of greasy breakfast fare. My friend had the huevos rancheros...which were pretty good. I had one of their samples...buttermilk pancakes with fresh berries...yum! He raved about the scones, which I thought tasted more like real homemade southern biscuits (which was fine, but more of an inaccurate description). 

Its a great alternative to places like Home...but is in a strange location unless you are on your way out of town via the GG Bridge.
author: Jenn G.

description:
5 STARS for the SCONES!!! (only)

What attracted me to this place was the poster saying "Voted Best Breakfast in Town".  But I would beg to differ.  If it said "Voted Best SCONES in Town" I would believe that.  They are completely fresh out of the oven and comes w/ and awesome awesome jam (i think these might be homemade too).

Be prepared for a bit of a wait on weekends...being a small hole in the wall place, it gets pretty crowded.  Parking kinda sucks too.   

SCONES! SCONES!! SCONES!!!
author: Elaine L.

description:
I really have nothing bad to say about Home Plate. I couldn't get enough of the freshly baked scones with APPLE BUTTER. Yum. I was all over that. Luckily, we came with a friend who used to work here, so we got a second helping of scones. My friend and I split two specials - a chicken scramble and buttermilk pancakes topped with a variety of fruit. The pancakes were perfectly crisp on the edges and fluffy on the inside, and the chicken scramble surprisingly had a lot of meat in it. I normally expect scrambles to be 90% egg, 10% meat, but this was almost 50/50. It was pretty bustling when I came, and I spent part of my meal marveling at the one chef in the kitchen who was churning out everything without our having to wait too long.

I'll spare you the obvious 'it was a grand slam!' line, and just say that I thoroughly enjoyed my meal here. Low key, cheap, and goood.
author: Erika C.

description:
Only got a chance to eat here once, but it was great. Got a quick, cheap and delicious breakfast. It was accompanied by a great little scone. I paid my bill and walked out satisfied with the food and the price.

If I ever get the chance, I'll make sure to bring my whole family here for a great breakfast.
author: Jason A.

description: My morning breakfast place. They serve a freshly baked scone that comes with jam (now who doesn't like jam) Portion sizes are huge and the prices are very reasonable. I wish they were open past 3:00, but beggars can't be choosers..
author: Dennis A.

description:
Breakfast is back!

The old Breakfast scenario:  Leave a morning of sleeping-in unfinished to wait in line and pay $20 for eggs which would have cost you $1.

Home Plate scenario: Tiny spot in an otherwise hyper-commercial area that offers consistent  goodness, normally without a huge wait, and more importantly without a huge tab.

Love the scones - imagine a sweet muffin from Popeye's, minus the fatty nastiest of fast-food hell.

From the simple two eggs and bacon, to the specialties like the suprisingly savory Corn Beef Hash, Home Plate has fast become my favorite breakfast spot. They serve lunch too in case you slept in too late. 

WATCH OUT for parking - DO NOT drive onto Chestnut looking for parking as it is a mommy and baby's wasps nest and it'll take you 15 mintues to get out.  And secondly, do not order item by item as the side dishes add up fast.
author: Robert F.

description:
Not bad. Not great.  It's a diner. There's some high points and some low points.

According to my server this morning, Home Plate has been here for 13 years, so they get bonus points for longevity. Unfortunately, so has some of the furniture apparently, because some of it has that years-old layers of grime and grease that even a good scrubbing can be hard-pressed to handle.

The highlight of my visit was fresh, hot, teeny-tiny drop biscuits (that they call scones) served with yummy fruit preserves.  And since the scones come with every breakfast, you automatically get to try one if you go.
But it was downhill from there. I was really looking forward to a good potato pancake (like the ones I had recently at suppenkuche), but the two that came with my breakfast this morning were undercooked, despite being grilled until blackened -- the potatoes just didn't have a yummy soft/crispy texture like a good potato pancake needs!
Plus, my side of wheat toast was buttered in that most-annoying fashion: dot in the middle with none on the edges.

And the final insult to me on this frigid January morning: Home Plate has no central heating. So the dining room was hat, scarf, and mitten-worthy.  Brrrr!
author: Jess S.

description: Cute well lighted cafe for breakfast in the Marina.   We had the pancakes with home-made sausage and Hangtown fry.  Both were excellent.  The pancakes had a little crisp to the edges and tasted like they were from a home-made batter.  The Hangtown fry had sufficient  They came with the oft-mentioned home made scones, home made strawberry and apple jams, crispy little apple-carrots pancakes with sour cream, and the never-ending coffee.    Total cost with tip was a little over  $25.  We were filled and  caffeinated.  There are daily specials and the standard breakfast menu gives you a variety of breakfast offerings so food boredom does not set in.  All the food is served with attention and a smile.   What is not to like?   Rush over tomorrow and enjoy the most important meal of the day.
author: Wilfred L.

description:
Uggh.

One of those places you just 'wanted' to like...I love the diner idea and definitely has that diner charm...Moreover, that they've been there for 18 years or something gives it more cache.

Yet, a couple of things stood out on the bad side...Espresso...Yeah, I'm a coffee snob and wonderful that they choose to go with an established and high end bean in Illy but having a crappy machine to scorch it kinda makes it almost worthless...Very disappointing, I hear the regular drip coffee is a much better way to go...As for the food, loved the 'idea' of the Supreme Scramble on the White Board only to find it included ingredients NOT mentioned in the liste of ingredients...Isn't that kinda defeating the point of listing them in the first place?...Ended up getting a workout to dissect the omelette which only ended up to be average.

Best part of the diner for breakfast?...Homemade scones...Pretty tasty I have to say...Had a little bite from the plates of friend's I was with to try out their selections and just found everything to be kinda average...Nothing special.

Apart from that, can't honestly say I'd be back.
author: Barca F.

description:
I just had brunch here this morning and it's a cute little place in the Marina that serves a variety of brunch items with lots of specials.  We got there a little early and avoided the crowd that formed outside by the time we left.  Their servers were great and my coffee cup never seemed to be less than half-full.

Their scones come warm and with butter on the side.  I enjoyed my scramble with chicken-apple sausage, veggies, and cheese that also came with potato pancakes.  This place had decent food but nothing too spectacular.  Perhaps I should have had the eggs benedict?  I don't know.  What I do know is that my husband would have preferred going to IHOP, which happens to be just across the street from Home Plate and their corned beef hash was a little dry.  They call it "chunky" for a reason.
author: Nina L.

description:
I love this place!  I will actually take a cab there and back to have breakfast here (and I live in Alamo Square).  That's how good it is.

I've been here three times in the past 6 weeks, and each time the food was delicious and the service was impeccable.  It also seems that this restaurant is an oasis of down-to-earthiness (is that a word?) in tourist / yuppie-land.  

I recommend the buckwheat pancakes, specifically the Home Plate Special, I believe it's called, which comes with two pancakes or waffles, eggs and your choice of bacon, sausage, etc.  Also, if you're the type who has a mimosa with brunch, try the Lychee Licious for a tasty spin on the old standby.  

Anyway, you'll like it.  Go!!!
author: Martine D.

description: Potato Carrot Pancakes are SOOO good!  Great friendly staff!  Excellent food!  Will be back!
author: Jodi B.

description:
I wanted to give this place 3 stars because the food was good but not great.  But I liked the casual atmosphere and laidbackness of the place so I figured that was worth an additional star.  It could have used some background music as it was super quiet in there.

I was the only person there as I got quite a late start to my day (I will never drink Everclear again.  EVER!) and strolled in for a 4 p.m. breakfast.  I had a veggie omelette which was done in the way I don't like it, where all the stuff is cooked and then the egg is placed on top of it all.  I prefer the ingredients to be inside the omelette and I imagine they would prefer it there too.  Nice and warm and all.  

Mark, the owner and cook, was very welcoming and we chatted for a while after I was done eating.  It's the kind of place I would go to often if it was right around the corner.
author: Emile B.

description: Home Plate holds a very special place in my heart, as it was the spot where I enjoyed my first breakfast in San Francisco way back in '91! I've been braving the Marinaites for years in order to enjoy their early morning vittles and strong coffee. They have a solidly good menu and the service has always been super friendly. I love the scones and potato pancakes -- a nice touch and quite tasty! I'm glad my MTASS (Marinaite Toleration and Anti-Avoidance Satisfaction System) is still functioning because this place doesn't fail when it comes to good food!
author: Loretta G.

description:
It's inexpensive, walking distance from my friend's apartments, and the scones and potato pancakes are good (with the apple compote).  It seems like they make everthing in-house, which is surprising considering how far their menu spans.  I've gotten the huevos rancheros both visits, and for a morning after a little too much liquid fun, it gets the job done.  

On the other hand, if you don't order when they first approach, be prepared to wait a little longer, and carefully ration out your water, as one glass will need to last for your entire meal.
author: Katie M.

description: Couldn't beat this place for friendliness.  Loved that they kept the water glass and coffee cup filled.  Extensive menu.  A winner!
author: John S.

description: Really yummy. Pesto omlette was great. We went on a Saturday around 11am. There was a bit of a wait, but it wasn't too bad. The food came quickly and they give you a scone app. I love breakfast apps. Can't go wrong with that. I'll go back again!
author: Erica K.

description: A bunch of family was in town and we had them staying near by.  We ate here four mornings.  The service was fantastic.  We had many things on the menu and all were good!
author: Scott K.

description: Home Plate offers one of the best breakfasts in the City. Try their Hangtown Oyster Fry, Turkey Hash, Banana Pancakes, and scones.  The new owner are friendly, open to suggestion and hard working.  I love this plac
author: joe r.

description:
overall lackluster service and very hit or miss food. Sometimes entrees will vary on days in taste (depending on cook I guess), I've waited 10-40 minutes to get my bill to leave on average. 

Their scones are great, one of the reasons I still come.

as long as its not too busy, service is reasonably fast (unless the cook is alone and the server is intensely arguing with somebody else in Cantonese)
author: Haoming C.

description: Great brunch place!! Scones with strawberry and mango preserves are delicious!! Got scrambled eggs w chicken apple sausage, herbs, mushrooms, cheese. Very tasty! Wasn't crazy about the potato carrot pancake as it is really flat and just tastes like fried mashed potato to me. I tried my friend's hash browns and they were yummier! Good value, small restaurant, so def not good for large parties.
author: Alexa L.

description: Eggs and chorizo killer, handmade tortillas, chocolate chip pancakes $3.50 little one couldn't finish them. So good. I Googled, used navigation on smart phone and Viola. So worth it!! Cheap and homemade goodness
author: Willow L.

description: the breakfast starter lacked taste. but unlimited iced coffee and the service made this place alright. friends got the chorizo and eggs which was really good (and reminded me of taco bell mmmmmm). i heard the sausage patties were bland as well. it's a small quaint place which has a nice feel, just wish it tasted better.
author: Andrew A.

description: Yummy food. The free chocolate scones were excellent. Service was 5 stars.
author: Kim M.

description: OK, so they give you free scones that are pretty tasty, but that doesn't mitigate the fact that Home Plate serves a seriously bad breakfast. Our egg dishes were borderline-inedible, both because of their unsightly appearance and the stench of dirty dishes that pervades the stuffy little restaurant space. Oh, and the place was filled with crying babies throughout our entire meal. You've been warned.
author: Heather F.

description: It may be a bit of a dive, but you won't find a better breakfast/brunch in San Francisco.  If there is a wait (and there can be on weekends) it is completely worth it.  My go to is the turkey eggs benedict with the potato pancakes.  The scones they give you to start are outstanding.  Their side orders of fruit are also worth ordering of you want to be a little healthy.
author: Heath T.

description: I've been meaning to check this place out for years and I finally did yesterday...stumbled in at around 11:30 am seeking to alleviate the slight hangover from the night before's Halloween festivities. So worth it! They served us currant scones that were divine! They were little and warm and perfectly crumbly and only sweetened by the raisins. I slathered them in butter and the delicious home-made strawberry jam. I ordered the Denver omelette and it was okay. It came with carrot-potato pancakes. My boyfriend ordered a side of the potato carrot pancakes that came with sour cream and yummy cinnamon-y  applesauce and the homemade fried mushroom, Parmesan cheese, pine-nut polenta that was so good.   The place was packed with a pretty diverse across-the-ages crowd--a nice change from most Marina brunch places. Also nice was the fact that we got out of there for under $20. The food and the atmosphere are unpretentious and the portions are generous.  A VERY nice change for the Marina.  I'd go back for the scones alone!
author: Dee I.

description: I've been there once and can mainly remember them having good coffee, descent breakfast, and dirt cheap. They have some kind of potato pancake thing which is not very good. I would only go back if I were in the neighborhood and wanted fast service at very reasonable prices. There just wasn't anything special about it.
author: Kimberly H.

description: Still really good after all these years. Love the scones with fresh fruit spread and the potato latkes. Love the build-your-own scramble.
author: L J.

description: This is by far one of the best breakfast places I've been to in my life,  based on sheer taste and quality of food. Prices are very affordable, and the service is friendly. The freshly baked scones and home-made jam are simply delectable.
author: Melanie K.

description: Breakfast was a delight.  The scones were fabulous and the mango and strawberry preserves were even better.  The crab cakes benedict was spectacular. And the best part was the service!!!
author: Faith S.

description:
i can't believe everyone is so stuck on the hot fresh scones (wonderful, of course) but the real treat here is the craziness of food combinations. some creative genius in the back is throwing together some ridiculous breakfast plates. look on the white board! feast your eyes!
it's the new best breakfast ever!!
author: Stephanie C.

description: Are you kidding me? Best scones in the city. Hell fucking yeah.
author: Beth W.

description: My friend and I went a year ago when we were up in the bay area (based on YELP reviews) and again this past week (again visiting).  Great breakfast.  Good selection of things to eat.  They give you plenty of food.  And the scones (which is included with your breakfast) comes with a puree'd strawberry jam or mango jam with phenomenal.   We were staying in the Nob Hill area so it is quite a trek - but definitely work the walk!
author: MARIA T.

description: Delicious.. best scones and jam.. everything is fantastic and they are quick to serve but not quick to get you out.. enjoy the NY sunday times and good conversation...
author: Aimee C.

description: Home Plate a.k.a HEAVEN!!!  I love this tiny joint.  The scones are to die for and I would live off of them if I could (maybe I'll try).  The breakfast is all I've had there but thus far it has been excellent each time.  I think that's due to the amazing man behind the counter who is always there cooking and always wearing a smile.  He's a kitchen God of some sort, this I am sure of.  He puts something happy into the food when he cooks and you can taste it.  I always leave with a smile on my face, a full belly and (when I'm lucky) a bag of scones to go!  I hate to tell anyone about the place and yet I couldn't imagine not showing them some love...
author: Talia L.

description:
Its been a while since I've been to this place (pre-yelp years)- and decided to give it a go- forgoing the corporate IHOP across the street to support this mom and pop place (Yes sounds like the movie "You've Got Mail" )...

One star is for the prompt and efficacious service!  By the time we had the menu at hand- coffee and tea was pouring in to our cups :-)  The second star is for the menu- because you can really get creative with the omelettes with the varying fixin's from spinach to chicken liver.  Anyhoo- I ordered the eggs benedict- a little disappointing- I think the hollandaise was from a packet- it was strangely too tangy and yellow- sorry I have this thing about artificial colorings...my roommate had the Turkey Supreme special made of an open face sandwich with turkey, avocado and tomatoes- it was delectable and just right... the potato pancakes were overcooked and brown- like it oxidized for a while...Im afraid the third strike here is the scones- which lacked grandeur being flat and tiny :-(  I always picture scones being large and heavy...I do give it half a star for being warm and home made ...Our meal was not a home run- but like any baseball game- wait until the next inning.
author: Arissa C.

description: I just remembered about this place. A relative took me here many years ago and the only memory that sticks are the scones. Soft, warm, and delicious. The breakfast is decent, but all I wanted were the scones. I think it's time for another visit.
author: Leroid D.

description: One of the better breakfast spots I've found in the Marina/Cow Hollow area.  Especially good omelets.  A bit high priced for a small breakfast joint, but the food is really fresh and made with care -- yeah, worth it once in awhile.  Serves breakfast relatively late for your weekend sleepins....
author: Jack H.

description: They have great breakfast plates, and the FREE freshly baked scones are  heaven!  I never really liked scones before coming to this place.  They are so warm and fluffy and come with an awesome homemade jam.  Mmm Mmm GOOD!
author: Chris Y.

description: Very good breakfast place! Like other reviewers, I must rave about the Scones. Absolutely yummy. I just wish it was possible to dine on just the scones. They are that good. I also really love the pancakes and buttermilk waffles here. Great breakfast place and the neighborhood is a hell of a lot better than that where Dottie's resides.
author: Anita B.

description:
Ah - what is wrong with me?  It is like I didn't have taste buds or something on my most recent trip to Home Plate.  We came here for breakfast this weekend - I got the special which included two pieces of bacon, two eggs and two pancakes -- not to mention the scones that come out right when you sit down.  So with all of that food, you would think I would be more satisfied.  My bacon was pretty tasty, the raisin scone hit the spot.  The eggs - I couldn't even tell by taste they were eggs.  The pancakes - to thick and too over-cooked, kind of reminded me what a hockey-puck would taste like.
I mean - you don't come to Home Plate for ambiance you come here for really good breakfast/diner food.  So as we were sitting there I told the BF that this place was a 2 maybe a 3 -- and then to come home, log onto Yelp and find that other Yelpers have decided this place is worth 4 stars, again I ask - what is wrong with me?
author: Katie P.

description: Breakfast was wonderful, the place was kind of grungy which I liked....it's probably a great place to attempt to cure a hangover. I find it ironic that it's right across from an IHOP....
author: Nichole H.

description: Greasy-spoon is right (as mentioned on others reviews)!  I think I ordered the wrong thing.  I should have ordered one of the fritattas, but wanted something sweet and savory and went for "the special"--2 eggs, 2 bacon and your choice of pancakes, waffles or french toast.  I think the saving grace would be the free scones that come with the meal.  Would consider going there again if I was in the area, but not so much willing to make the trek out there (from the inner Richmond district).
author: Marie B.

description: Do not listen to the other reviewers.  Hands down worst breakfast ever!!  The eggs were not cooked and the fritta was so greasy it was inedible. Scones were average at best.  Smelled gross.  Bad service.  Yuck.  Do not eat here.
author: Jennifer N.

description: Truly a greasy spoon, which I am not opposed to, but the food here just isn't what I thought it was going to be. I got a scramble which had good ingredients. I liked the addition of the roasted chicken, it's just the food was lacking in flavor. The free scone was good, certainly not the best in the city as someone had claimed. I probably wouldn't go here again unless I had already found parking here. It can be a total pain.
author: Erik S.

description: My bf and I have been here many times.  The quality before has been consistent so we were surprised when we went in this morning and were so disappointed to find that the coffee was lukewarn and the corned beef hash had barely no corned beef in it.  We won't be going back again, unfortunately.
author: C L.

description: I like the down-home feel of this place and would probably eat here every sunday morning if I lived in the area. The reason why I don't give it anything above 3 stars is because the food is only average. I had the savory cakes, which were nowhere near savory. The eggs were fine, but how can you go wrong with sunny-side up eggs? I did find the scones DELICIOUS. Maybe if this was a cafe and all I had were the scones and coffee, then I would give it 4 stars. The funniest thing was when my friend asked the owner "Do you have a restroom?" and she replied "Freshly squeezed orange juice? Coming right up!" hahhah. We were all fearful of what we'd get when we asked for the check!
author: Charlene C.

description: It's rare for me to wind up at Home Plate on a Sunday morning. I don't like Pac Heights and Marina girls, and they most certainly wouldn't demean themselves to be pawed at by a man that makes less than six figures.  Unless, of course,  they've been pounding gin and tonics all night which is where I come in. So on a couple of occasions I've slid head first into home plate and it did the trick.
author: lazslo t.

description: A greasey spoon with solid, simple breakfast stuff for cheap.  Waiter guy seemed pretty grumpy, and its not a place for 'ambience', but its hard to find a meal in S.F. - esp in the Marina - for under $10.  I'm not much of a scone guy, but they ARE pretty good.
author: Ryan W.

description: Scones are the best I have ever had here.  If you get the specials, then order the chicken omelets, or one of their many omelets they have available.  Most of the time these are pretty good.  Pancakes and french toast is reminiscent of a college dinning common, but tasty.  Overall, an above average place for breakfast.
author: Kapeli M.

description:
Every week, I haveto stop by my favorite little hole in the wall breakfast joint.  From what I can tell, it's owned by a family of Koreans (?) and they happily serve you the best breakfast on Lombard all morning.  

The highlights are easily the little scones you get in the beginning with their homemade fresh jam.  I haven't tried much else other than the corned beef and poached eggs.  Bite sized chunks of fresh corned beef with onions and bell peppers with a perfectly poached egg over it.  Awesome.
author: Peter C.

description: We've been going to this restaurant for 18 years and will still make the trek up from the peninsula with our kids for a special treat.  The pancakes, egg dishes and scones are really tasty.  It's not fanciest and it's clearly in need of some sprucing up - but, for us, it's an institution which I hope stays around a long time.  Now that I am a vegan, my options are a lot more limited but it's still great for the kids and anyone else looking for a traditional breakfast.
author: Wendy K.

description:
pretty good standard breakfast fare...a couple of out of the ordinary things...

I have to agree with all previous yelp reviews....the scones were the standout...

my friend that was dining with me was tempted to stick her hand in the oven and grab some fresh ones...that's how good they were...

(oh and the lemonade....we think is actually limeade..)
author: Joy Y.

description:
Looking at the reviews, everyone is right on the mark.  

My meal seemed promising with the delicious scones and I think "strawberry butter"? Not sure but it tasted like an apple butter with strawberries, not really a jam. 

Anyhow, the waitress misheard me and I decided to just live with the meal I received (just breakfast, no biggie). 

However, the potato pancakes were rubbery and just not right. My special scramble was kind of watery with too many herbs.  The housemade sausage is a little on the bland side and I needed lots of tabasco.  I may go back though to try the cornmeal pancakes....

Menu is extensive, so maybe they need to scale back a bit and focus on the details.
author: Mya P.

description: Yeah, it's a greasy spoon... but it's a terrific greasy spoon. The specials and fritattas are... inventive to say the least, and the cornmeal pancakes are fantastic. Not everything there is top of the line, but the free scones, potato carrot pancakes, and homemade chicken apple sausage patties are not to be missed. It's also fairly easy on the wallet. As a special bonus, you can gaze out the window at the worst IHOP in the world, and shake your head with condescension at everyone who enters.
author: Cameron S.

description:
Here is my bullet point review as I'm a student and I'm tired of writing papers.
-Had to ask twice for water and for ketchup.  Some of the worst service I've experienced in SF.
-Scone and the purple sauce was good.
-Egg dish was edible but not satisfying.
-Roll that came with the egg dish tasted like cardboard.

And my favorite part of the meal?  The guy hands me the check with no total written on it.  Ok buddy, here's my credit card.  Go ahead and charge whatever you think is appropriate for a sub-par breakfast and crappy service.

In conclusion - I'm never coming back.
author: Piper H.

description: No frills decor - but delicious fresh breakfast! Need I mention the amazing jam and biscuits again?
author: Jon B.

description: My husband and I live in the neighborhood and like doing brunch on the weekends.  We really like going here for a few reasons... it's a small business and we like supporting small business, the quality is good, and the price is GREAT.  We chatted with the owner one day and he was saying that with the economy as difficult as it is he has cut back on staff instead of lowering the quality of the products he uses or raising the prices.  The prices are VERY reasonable, and I know they don't skimp on their food.  A really good example is that they use an expensive syrup which is better quality as opposed to just cutting corners and using Cosco type of syrup.  It's real maple... not just goopy sugar.  The scones are ssssoooooo darn good I can't stand it!  I agree, the potato pancake things aren't great.  But overall, it's decent quality food and the price is right!
author: Dawn D.

description:
I live in the Marina so this is a local spot for me. As much as I adore The Grove on Chestnut, sometimes it's just a bit too 'Marina' in there for first thing in the morning, so I gladly escape to the more neutral atmosphere of Home Plate. 

The place does so much so well. I long to give it 5 stars, but it needs to tweak its act a little to become the perfect breakfast place it could so easily be. I'll agree with so many other reviews: the scones and potato-carrot pancakes are uniquely wonderful; the service is sweet and friendly and I love the people who run the place; the specials board has great and interesting dishes on it always; I have never had a bad meal here, it's all well cooked and tasty; yummy, fresh juice drinks like the Pep Supreme are fab; the place is un-Marina, homely, cozy and a bit retro. SO MUCH TO LOVE. 

Yet, it is also true: the place is grubby. Yes, verging on dirty. It needs a DEEP clean. They do re-use the fruit compote and that is gross. And yes, one of the tables is almost in the bathroom.

Oh, Home Plate, heed the reviews of those who love you. Turn over a new hygiene leaf, and lo, the masses will flock to thy gates. Amen.
author: Alison S.

description: hands down my favorite breakfast place in the city. The carrot potato pancakes are super yummy and come as a side dish with all breakfast items. Yummy fresh baked scones also come with every order.
author: Stacy H.

description: The servers at Home Plate know me by name, even though I live on the other side of the city.  Great potato pancakes, great scones, fresh jam, perfect on early weekday afternoons.  My companion always orders the chorizo and eggs, and swears by it.
author: Jude F.

description: This is a great breakfast place for cheap and good food! It's a very causal place for weekend brunch. The menu has so much to offer, it too my friend and I forever to make up our minds. There was so much we wanted to try.  Before we ordered, the waitress gave us hot raisin scones with strawberry jam. They tasted like they just came out of the oven. Yummy.  After debating between the oyster omelette and the greek fritta, I ended up ordering the fritta. My breakfast was huge!! The fritta was make with 3 eggs, spinach, olives, and feta cheese. It also came with two carrot and potato pancakes, applesauce, and a crescent dinner roll. The potato pancakes weren't that great, but I was really enjoyed my eggs.  The whole breakfast was only $7!!! I was definitely impressed with the quality and portions of the food. I would definitely go back to try the oyster omelette.
author: Denise L.

description: There are simply waaaay to many eateries in San Fran making it almost impossible to decide without the assistance of yelp....thank goodness for yelp. There were tons of other top choices in San Francisco in general, but for breakfast we wanted something closer by. Since we were staying in the Marina district Home Plate was top in this area so of course we ran with that, helped that it was down a few blocks from our hotel. We were here for the Memorial weekend so decided to go early around 9am. We found parking which was free since it was on Sunday, there was no wait, friendly staff, got our fresh hot coffee right away and the famouse scones and homade jam (rasin scone, appricot and strawberry jelly) they were simply deliciouse very delicate very much like a biscuit. My husband got chicken fried steak and he really liked it, it was perfectly battered and crispy, I got the crab benedict and it was really deliciouse, the hollandais sauce was a true hollandais, I don't understand but so many places can't manage to make this right for some sad reason? The poached egg was nice and runny the way it should, the potatoes were crispy and deliciouse. Prices were quite reasonable in my opinion for a hearty breakfast. Would definately recommend it.
author: BV M.

description: Great alternative to the overpriced brunch places in the city. As far as greasy spoons go, this place isnt even all that bad, consider it a part of its charm! Consider greasy diners in other cities as our fair city does not have many of those. Scramblers are great, ibid on the amazing scones and service aint so bad either. If you want to really avoid the crowd and have a day off during the week as opposed to weekend, thats the time to go.
author: Niki M.

description: Greasy spoon in the Marina.  Good for dinner style breakfast.
author: Andrew R.

description: Have been going here for half my life.  Scones are LEGIT.  Enough said.
author: Tony P.

description: i never knew breakfast could taste so good, and coming from me whose favorite meal is breakfast, that is a big, bold, huge, gigantic statement. the scones, the bacon, the eggs, the hash browns, the toast, the chocolate milk. everything right down to the last bite and sip was absolutely amazing. the textures and smells and sounds all meshed together to create a dining experience i want to have again. yeah, i had chocolate milk, what of it?
author: Katie B.

description: I agree, the warm scones and jam were great and they made me excited for the rest of my meal.  But once I tasted my waffle that reminded me of french fries cooked in tempura batter, and saw my friends runny eggs I was very disappointed.  Other items were just "alright".  Also service was so bad it was humorous.  Far too many good breakfast places in the city to bother with this one again.
author: Jennie J.

description:
i want to kick myself for all the times i settled for noah's or the grove or crepevine for breakfast!  how did i not know about this hidden gem so close to my casa??

the bf and i went on a monday (read: no wait) and had a fabulous time!!  

scones = delish, and im not even a scone person!  
scramble = heaven, i love picking my own combos!
french toast sampler = yummers, i like the whole wheat one the best!
potato pancake = fun alternative to hash browns, which are my favorite breakfast food!

and people, their mimosas are only $3.25, now that is a bargain...
author: Natalie H.

description: This is not a terrible neighborhood joint, it is just okay.  If it was not for all the damn tourists from the cheap motels across the st. it might be a moral appealing spot. How hard is it to mess up breakfast right?  Well the scones, as they like to call them are alright, my friend Andrew lives and dies by their breakfasts, as he ALWAYS has the blintzes? Not my idea of breakfast goodness, but whatever.  If they remodeled and had actual hash browns as oppose to faux potato pancakes, this might improve the rating.  You are not missing anything if you skip this spot.
author: Nicole F.

description: This is my first choice when driving into SF from Marin in the mornings. Service could be better though, but good enough.
author: Keith B.

description: The service can be somewhat unpredictable but the food has always been really good.  I love the oatmeal pancakes and add fresh berries.  They are always very accomodating if you want to substitute items.
author: Happy L.

description: I've been to this place twice.  The first time, I barely finished my meal.  It was incredibly unappetizing, but I thought "hey, maybe it's just me". So six months or so pass and my mother-in-law is out to visit.  The three of us set out to find a great breakfast, and since there was no wait, we decided to eat here, just in case my first trip there was a one time experience.  Well....it wasn't.  Aside from the scones which are killer, and the potato pancakes which are tasty as well, we each found the food to be nearly inedible.  My mother-in-law and I literally ate the pancakes and scones and barely touched the rest of our meal.  Two stars for the scones and pancakes,  but otherwise, we won't be back again.
author: Chrys W.

description:
A group of us went to Home Plate for lunch yesterday and it was sooo good.  I had a delicious and healthy grill shrimps salad.  The vegetable were fresh and the shrimps were plenty and large.  The salad dressing was light and flavorful.  I specially like the mandarin orange wedges in my salad.  One of my friend had club sandwich, came with a side of fresh salad.  She ate every thing on her plate.  Another friend had cobb salad and again it was completely gone by end of our lunch.  

Another thing we love about this place (under new owner) is her savory scone.  I have never have savory scone before and like another reviewer, not particularly like scone because it tends to be dry.  But this savory scone is moist and creamy, melt in your mouth.  So good.  It came with our lunch order.  You have to try it.

The new owner has made so much improvements that you can tell it is done with love for good food and good service.  I will keep going back as well as my friends.  I'm bringing more people to try this out.

Love it!!!
author: Victoria S.

description: This place is awesome for a filling and reasonably priced breakfast.  Their scones are the best...they make them from scratch...they are still warm when you get them.  The jam they serve with the scones is also killer! Their pancakes with fresh fruit are also really good.
author: Jaki B.

description: These scones are better than the ones your momma makes!  The wait can be a little long, but don't fret you'll be getting those scones in no time!  Seriously just try this place, I'll be your best friend promise!
author: Cassie L.

description: The scones here are delicious. There is usually a long line outside though, which is why i've only actually eaten here once, even though I've passed by many times and decided to go somewhere less busy (usually Bay Watch a few blocks down) Its pretty decent though, a little cramped, nothing really special, although you should try it at least once, just for the scones. Mm...scones...
author: Katrina C.

description: I love Home Plate!  The scones, the amazingly fruity pancakes, oh I'm hungry just thinking about it!
author: Nathalee S.

description: I know it's not the cleanest place in the world, but heck, what hole-in-the-wall diner is?  When I need a greasy, filling hungover breakfast meal, Home Plate is where I go.  The special omelettes and scrambles are awesome, and the scones are great too.  Don't let the small, run-down look of the place turn you off.
author: Dale M.

description: Home Plate is a delicious step up from a greasy spoon that I can't believe is located in the Marina. The staff is pretty no nonsense but the food is delicious. First of all, everything comes with a scone. Really good, home made, makes my mouth water thinking about them, scone. I ordered the chorizo scramble (can't go wrong with anything that has avocado) and it was divine. My dad wasn't as impressed with his BLT, but a BLT is a BLT so I don't know what he was expecting. I don't know why you would go across the street to IHOP when Home Plate is right there. I will definitely be returning.
author: Jessica B.

description:
I had seen this place before, and thought that it looked like it had potential for a good breakfast joint. Today, I went out and proved that idea wrong. This place is terrible: Terrible service, terrible atmosphere, terrible food.

No need to get into details, if you don't believe me, go find out for yourself. You WILL be disappointed.
author: Prairie D.

description: There aren't a lot of great places to go for breakfast in SF, but this is a good one.  It has that "greasy spoon" feel to the decor, but the food is great.  Try the turkey hash with cashews.
author: Sonia A.

description: This place used to be my favorite, but after going 3-4 times I'm over it. It is TOO dirty to eat there in peace. My boyfriend said he found a penny in the strawberry sauce they give you with the scones. The man working there is nice but I don't think the place is sanitary at all.
author: Cyndi C.

description: Home Plate is a good, fairly cheap breakfast spot.  It's nothing fancy; the decor looks worn, but the food is simple & tasty.  I love the Potato/Carrot pancakes w/Apple Butter & Sour Cream.  The home-made scone/croissants that accompany the breakfast selections are terrific.  Service is friendly & prompt.  Grabbing a filling breakfast at HP is a great way to start your day---you can work off those calories @ nearby Crissy Field!
author: steve c.

description: Good Food. Okay.  When it comes down to it I might eat here again, BUT the place was kind of gross.  Maybe that was just because I was facing the kitchen, watching the cook handle every item of food with his bare hands is weird to me.  Plus it was about 80 degrees inside with about 108% humidity.   Scones, Jam, and fresh foods were definitely a plus.  It was hard to get an appetite started.
author: Zachary S.

description: Great breakfast food especially on the weekends, but got to go there early before the crowd.  Husband and wife duo gives this place an inviting and warm feeling everytime we go.  I agree with most people, probably the BEST SCONCES west of the Mississippi!
author: Steve W.

description:
This is so far my FAVORITE breakfast place. They make homemade scones that come with your meal. They also make awesome potato-carrot pancakes which also comes with most dishes. You get pretty traditional breakfast items but with a unique family recipe twist. Yes, the people there are asian but they still make the best American breakfast ever!! 
This place gets very crowded on weekend mornings!
author: Kim M.

description:
Giving a 4 based solely on the food.

Like other yelpers comments - the scones were delicious.  The food was fantastic as well - lots of choices and very good price!

I couldn't help but think about the improvements I could do to the place with just $100 or $500!  Really...it wouldn't take a lot...even fresh paint on the walls and a cleaned floor would drastically improve the look.  Then add a few tables with newer chairs and matching newer plates...and bam, a hip Marina brunch place with amazing food and service!
author: JM W.

description:
Based on the wide range of reviews perhaps they are inconsistent but my very first experience was a good one that warrants a return visit. 

The tables were dirty and the decor was that of a no frills cheap diner. ok no surprises. A lot of homemade items though set this place apart. Free homemade scones were good with what appeared to be home made jam. My GF got Chorizo and eggs which were above par and had homemade salsa. I got the corned beef hash. Definitely not canned. Big chunks of pepper and corned beef, a poached egg and a side of horseradish cream. Um. Horseradish cream in a diner? Nice work. And I spied a cranberry and tomato mimosa on the specials board. Didn't try it but that sounds perfect for a hangover.

Its true there's no shortage of great breakfast places in the city, some of which you can expect to have horseradish cream and fancy inventive food, but this place is a diner with diner prices. It seems obvious to me that while they don't care much about making the place look fancy, they do take some pride in their food.
author: Pete L.

description: The slightly weather-worn sign on Lombard's no-tell motel row across from a vintage Ihop was disconcerting. But spartan exterior and simple table settings belie this gem of a coffee shop. First off, wonderful scones and home-made jellies. Friendly fun service. Every cook should wear a baseball hat on backwards if it makes the cook like this one. Spinach fritata, potato-carrot pancakes, home-made chicken sausage patties and agreeable if not remarkable coffee hit the spot. The buttermilk pancakes needed another minute of cooking, but otherwise a very nice breakfast. Got there at 10a.m. and sat right down; 30 minutes later there was a wait for a table.  About $12/person including coffee.
author: t m.

description: Not sure I understand the humor in the Chinese comment, but ok?  There's this great film I saw recently called Crash.  Everyone should check it out.  But back to the breakfast.  I kind of had mixed feelings about this place.  I absolutely loved the warm, melt in your mouth, scones with raisins.  You get 2 with your meal with a side of homemade strawberry marmalade and I'm telling you, both of these items are GOOD stuff.  I had finished my breakfast dish and felt compelled to order two more scones even though I was full.  Did I say yummy?  The rest of my breakfast was good...eggs...bacon...potatoes were medium sized chunks and cooked with onions.  The roll was ok. I wasn't feeling the complimentary potato and carrot pancakes with dipping sauce, but my boyfriend liked them.  His Denver Omelette was large and tasty.  The service was pretty slow and abrupt and I couldn't help thinking throughout my dining experience that they just needed ONE more person working in there, and the place would be so much better.  So I was leaning to an overall 3 rating based on the service, but the memory of the scones bumped it up to a 4 because they were oh sooo good.
author: LaSha G.

description: I cannot believe I have managed to not write about this awesome breakfast joint. UNBELIEVABLE scones. Homemade with homemade jam. Honestly its all you need BUT don't stop because their menu is amazing. Lemonade is perfecto. I love it everytime i go! Honestly my favorite breakfast place.
author: Padma K.

description: i've been coming to home plate for years and i have to admit it's one of my favorite breakfast places.  my favorite is the chicken omelette and their waffles rival ole's in alameda. the oj is freshly squeezed and their scones are delicious.  weekends can get crowded but that's a good sign of a quality establishment.  usually it's pretty easy getting a table during lunch on weekdays.  parking is available in a structure around the corner on pierce.
author: Leon C.

description: Great scones!  Best option on Lombard Street for a good, cost-effective breakfast.
author: Andi B.

description: Yummy home-made biscuits and jam!  Absolutely the best potato pancakes too.
author: nikki s.

description: It was billed to me as the best diner/breakfast food in town, but I wasn't terribly impressed. Didn't see any cockroaches, but the food was way too greasy even for diner food. I did like the vibe, though.
author: A. T.

description: Casual atmosphere for a laid back brunch/breakfast spot.  Good, solid food.  Love the homemade scones you get when you sit down.  Their cornmeal pancakes are also delicious.
author: Julie D.

description: Service was ok - met minimum service requirements.  Food was tasteless, except for the scones.
author: Allan B.

description: Great food. I love their buckwheat pancakes. I also adore the scones. One is never enough for me, so I usually order half a dozen to go. It gets really busy on weekends and holidays. I do drive half way across the city for breakfast, sometimes I don't know why. But I taste the scone and I never regret it.
author: bob k.

description: Been to this place for a few times but the last time I came for brunch with my boy friend, I decided not to come back ever again.  We were seated right next to the kitchen and I witnessed they recycled the apple sauce for the scones.  The chef and the servers at the restaurant didn't wear gloves and their hands touch everything you could think of.  It definitely ruined my appetite and I was disgusted by what I saw.  If you really want to try out this place, make sure you don't sit too close to the kitchen area.
author: Bella L.

description: ok, i must admit.  my boyfriend-fiance-husband has been a gigantic fan of this place for the entire 9 years we have known each other (see aforementioned cadence of our relationship during which he has consistently espoused that home plate is the best breakfast in town).  i have been such a brunch snob (read: only want to go to "cute" places even if the food sucks just because its cute and cute people go there) most of my existence so have always pooh-poohed the home plate.  but when you get right down to it, he is right on.  first of all, they give you delicious warm scones as you sit down (for free, people) with  home-made fruit compote.  then, the food is actually great breakfast fare.  be sure to stick to the white board of specials on the wall -- these are your best options -- previously mentioned bf-fi-hus ALWAYS gets the special scramble.  this "special" is always available.  the food is good (beyond the scones and the potato-carrot pankcakes), the service is good, and what's amazing is that the iron chef behind the counter makes everything himself.  it's a one-chef, family owned place.  so break away from cute, if you can, and head to home plate for some good breakfast grub.
author: Lija H.

description: I used to love this place. it USED to be really good.. I went last month for my birthday breakfast and it was DISGUSTING! My egg dish ( I can't even remember which one it was) appeared that an entire bottle of dried oregano had been dropped into it. I sent it back saying that it was in-edible due to this oregano and chose another plate that also was semi-edible. I thought it odd that the waitress left that oregano plate on our table and then when the bill came, I see why. She wanted me to pay for this in-edible dish. Now I'm not a picky eater and I understand that I need to eat what I choose, but do I need to pay for the chef's mistake? I called her back to our table and she was so angry with us, but did take it off the bill. Also the potato pancakes used to be delicious, now I have no idea what they are putting in them. They are like a piece of greasy pizza cardboard. I am really sad because I really used to like this place. it seems now that they are catering to the Lombard Street tourists and think they won't be seeing any of these people again so they have cut a lot of corners. Next time I'll be going to IHOP for a fluffy chain pancake.
author: Julia J.
